bestBHT.bht: For I have none else like-minded, who will really care for your affairs and order them for the best. Timothy, in his rare excellence, had a soul like the apostle's, sharing the same judgment and doctrines of grace. Paul regarded Timothy as a son, sending him on this important message to demonstrate the depth of his concern for their state. There was no one equally well-affected for attending to their interests.

Henry Alford: For I have none else like-minded...who will really care for your affairs."
None else like-minded...to order them for the best."
Will really care for your affairs, to order them for the best.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I have none so 'like-minded,' literally, 'like-souled,' with myself as is Timothy.
A case wherein the Spirit of God so changed man's nature, that to be natural was with him to be spiritual.
The great point to be aimed at.
Albert Barnes: There was no one with him who would feel so deep an interest in their welfare.
He would regard their interests with a sincere tenderness and concern.
Paul regarded Timothy as a son, and Paul’s sending him on such an occasion would evince the feelings of a father who should send a beloved son on an important message.
Marvin Vincent: Like minded [ισοψυχον] Only here in the New Testament."
Who [οστις] . Double relative, classifying : such that he."
Naturally [ψνησιως] . Rev., truly. The adverb only here in the New Testament.
John Calvin: I have no one equally well-affected for attending to your interests.
Paul ... compares Timothy with others, rather than with himself.
He pronounces this eulogium upon him, with the express design that he may be the more highly esteemed by them for his rare excellence.
Philip Schaff: For I have no man like-minded.
Who will care truly for your state.
It is the thought which admits no rest till the object of it is quite secured, and hardly then, but finds new anxiety for itself.
Archibald T. Robertson: Likeminded with Timothy, not with Paul.
John Gill: Timothy had a soul like the apostle's, which none that were with him, besides him, had; he was of the same judgment with him in the doctrines of grace.
he had an anxious care and solicitude, as the word signifies, for the good of souls.
he had a sincere love, an hearty and real concern for their good; and which he would show by delivering to them the sincere milk of the word.
John Wesley: I have none — Of those who are now with me.

bhtAttempts.bht: For I have none else like-minded, who will really care for your affairs and order them for the best. Timothy, in his rare excellence, had a soul like the apostle's, sharing the same judgment and doctrines of grace. He had a sincere love and a genuine concern for the Philippians' welfare, showing his care through delivering the sincere milk of the word. Paul regarded Timothy as a son, sending him on this important message to demonstrate the depth of his concern for their state. Indeed, amongst all those with him, there was no one equally well-affected for attending to their interests.

There was no one equally well-affected for attending to their interests.
